questions.text: A 75-year-old patient with long-standing atrial fibrillation (AF) received a VVIR pacemaker. After a few months, he presents with dizziness, fatigue, and visible pulsations in the neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pacemaker syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Pacemaker syndrome is a collection of symptoms caused by a loss of atrioventricular (AV) synchrony due to ventricular pacing. This can occur in patients with single-chamber pacemakers (like VVIR) who have underlying sinus node dysfunction (as suggested by the history of AF).

 

The symptoms of pacemaker syndrome include:

 

  • Dizziness and fatigue: Due to decreased cardiac output caused by loss of AV synchrony.
  • Visible neck pulsations: Prominent irregular cannon A waves in the JVP due to atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sick sinus syndrome: Would not be associated with elevated JVP or cannon ‘a’ waves.

 

Option C. Lead displacement: Lead displacement would likely cause pacing failure or erratic pacing, not the specific symptoms described.

 

Option D. Ventricular tachycardia: This would present with a rapid, regular heart rhythm and different symptoms (palpitations, chest pain, syncope).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Pacemaker syndrome is a potential complication of single-chamber ventricular pacing (usually VVIR), and presents with dizziness and syncope due to AV dissociation.

questions.text: What is the most common mechanism of digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delayed afterdepolarizations (DADs)

 

Option B:

 

Digitalis toxicity leads to an increase in intracellular calcium levels within cardiac myocytes. This calcium overload triggers abnormal electrical impulses known as delayed afterdepolarizations (DADs) that occur during phase 4 of action potential. These DADs can reach a threshold and initiate ectopic beats, leading to various ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Re-entry: While re-entry is the most common mechanism for arrhythmias in general, it's not the primary mechanism for digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Early afterdepolarizations (EADs): EADs are associated with prolonged repolarization (long QT syndrome), which is not a direct effect of digitalis toxicity.

 

Option D. Enhanced automaticity: Although digitalis can increase automaticity, it's not the predominant mechanism; DADs caused by calcium overload play a more significant role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the primary mechanism of digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias is delayed afterdepolarizations (DADs) caused by intracellular calcium overload.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the AV node accurately?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decremental response

 

Option A:

 

Atrionodal transitional connections exhibit decremental conduction, defined as slowing of conduction with increasingly rapid rates of stimulation. This property of the atrioventricular (AV) node is physiologically important. If a very rapid atrial arrhythmia occurs, the AV node acts as a sort of “gatekeeper” to the ventricles due to its decremental conduction. Thus, in the case of atrial fibrillation (where atrial rates often exceed 300 beats/min) the ventricular rate never approaches these very rapid rates. Some accessory conduction pathways, in contrast, do not exhibit decremental conduction properties and will very rapidly conduct tachycardias (such as atrial fibrillation) to the ventricles, leading to hemodynamic collapse.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sodium-dependent conduction: The action potential upstroke in the AV node is dependent on the smaller and slower inward Ca2+ current, which is the reason why the upstroke velocity of the action potential is low—one of the factors responsible for the slow conduction velocity in the AV node.

 

Option C. Increased gap junctions: The AV node actually has fewer gap junctions than other parts of the conduction system, contributing to its slower conduction speed.

 

Option D. Speed of conduction is 1-2 m/s: The conduction speed in the AV node is much slower, around 0.05 m/s (50 mm/s).

 

Educational Objective:

 

AV node acts as a ‘gatekeeper’ to the ventricles.

choices.text: Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block
Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block

questions.text: You are seeing Mr. Aravind, a 24-year-old previously healthy athlete, for his routine physical examination. Which of the following rhythms is demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block

 

Option B:

 

The periodic failure of conduction in Mobitz type I block is characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause that is less than two times the immediately preceding RR interval on the electrocardiogram (ECG). The ECG complex after the pause exhibits a shorter PR interval than that immediately preceding the pause. This ECG pattern most often arises because of decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the atrioventricular node. This rhythm is usually benign and may be seen in very fit athletes due to high vagal tone. This pattern is typically caused by decremental conduction in the atrioventricular (AV) node. It is generally a benign rhythm and can be seen in healthy athletes due to high vagal tone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. First-degree heart block: This has a prolonged but constant PR interval.

 

Option C. Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block: This has a constant PR interval with occasional dropped QRS complexes.

 

Option D. Type III heart block (complete heart block): This has complete dissociation between the atria and ventricles, with no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mobitz type I second-degree heart block (Wenckebach) is a relatively benign rhythm often seen in athletes due to high vagal tone.

choices.text: Accessory pathway in the posteroseptal region

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of high risk in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Refractory period > 240ms

 

Option B:

 

A short refractory period of the accessory pathway (is a high-risk feature in WPW syndrome, as it allows for rapid conduction of impulses from the atria to the ventricles, potentially leading to life-threatening arrhythmia. A refractory period > 240 ms indicates a slower conduction pathway and is generally considered low risk. Also, exercise TMT demonstrating disappearance of the delta wave and wide QRS at HR ≥ 120 beats/min is also considered low risk since it indicates inability of the accessory pathway to conduct at higher rates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple pathways: The presence of multiple accessory pathways increases the risk of arrhythmias and is a high-risk feature.

 

Option C. Inducible AF or AVRT: The ability to induce AF or AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) during electrophysiology study indicates a higher risk of spontaneous arrhythmias and is a high-risk feature.

 

Option D. Accessory pathway in the posteroseptal region: Poster septal accessory pathways are associated with a higher risk of sudden cardiac death due to their potential to conduct rapidly during AF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High risk in WPW = multiple accessory pathways, accessory pathway refractory period < 240ms, inducible AVRT or AF in EPS & shortest RR in AF ≤ 250ms.

choices.text: It relies on enhanced automaticity as a mechanism.
It relies on multiple pathways for conduction from the atrium into the AV node.
It requires systemic anticoagulation for thromboembolic prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the most common form of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It relies on multiple pathways for conduction from the atrium into the AV node.

 

Option C:

 

The most common form of PSVT is atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). AVNRT is caused by the presence of multiple pathways within or near the AV node, allowing for re-entry circuits to form and sustain the tachycardia. Most forms of AVNRT utilize a slowly conducting AV nodal pathway that is located as a right inferior extension that extends from the compact AV node near the His bundle, inferiorly along the tricuspid valve annulus to the floor of the coronary sinus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is usually life-threatening:  AVNRT is usually not life-threatening, though it can cause significant symptoms.

 

Option B. It relies on enhanced automaticity as a mechanism:  AVNRT is a re-entry tachycardia, not caused by enhanced automaticity.

 

Option D. It requires systemic anticoagulation for thromboembolic prophylaxis: Anticoagulation is not typically required for AVNRT unless there are additional risk factors for thromboembolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common form of PSVT is AVNRT, which is caused by re-entry circuits involving multiple pathways within the AV node.

choices.text: Normal residual volume (RV)
Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC)
Normal vital capacity (VC)
Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of smoking and progressive dyspnea presents with a barrel chest and expiratory wheezing. Which PFT finding is LEAST likely in this patient with suspected emphysema?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal residual volume (RV)

 

Explanation:

 

Emphysema, a type of COPD, is characterized by air trapping and hyperinflation, leading to increased residual volume.

 

Other options

 

Option B. Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC): Common in emphysema due to air trapping.

 

Option C. Normal vital capacity (VC): While possible in early disease, VC often decreases as emphysema progresses.

 

Option D. Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio: Hallmark of obstructive lung disease like emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In emphysema, expect increased residual volume (RV) due to air trapping, along with decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and forced vital capacity (FVC).

choices.text: Normal lung function
Restrictive lung disease
Upper airway obstruction
Obstructive lung disease

questions.text: A patient's flow-volume (FV) loop demonstrates the following (red line in the image is the patients actual FV loop, background blue line is the predicted normal). What does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive lung disease

 

Explanation:

 

The concave shape with scooped appearance of expiratory limb and reduced PEFR on the expiratory limb are classic for obstructive lung diseases like COPD and asthma, indicating airflow limitation during exhalation. The patient also has a near normal FVC, further strengthening the diagnosis of obstruction.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Normal lung function: Normal flow-volume loops are relatively linear.

 

Option B. Restrictive lung disease: Usually shows a smaller loop with normal shape.

 

Option C. Upper airway obstruction: Typically shows flattening on the inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A concave, scooped expiratory flow-volume loop with reduced PEFR is indicative of obstructive lung disease such as COPD or asthma.

questions.text: You are in the emergency department when a 19-year-old woman, Ms. Vidhya, arrives after collapsing during a Sunday marathon. She is unresponsive and pulseless. ECG is shown. Which of the following rhythms is the cause of her cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial fibrillation with pre-excitation

 

Option A:

 

Rapid, irregular, broad complex tachycardia (overall rate ~ 200 bpm) with a LBBB morphology (dominant S wave in V1). This could easily be mistaken for AF with LBBB.

 

However, the morphology is not typical of LBBB, the rate is too rapid (up to 300 bpm in places, i.e. too rapid to be conducted via the AV node), and there is a subtle beat-to-beat variation in the QRS width which is more typical of WPW (LBBB usually has fixed width QRS complexes).

 

The rhythm is very difficult to differentiate from polymorphic VT but it does not have the twisting morphology to consider it as Torsades de pointes.

 

Note: Approximately 25% of APs causing preexcitation allow minimum R-to-R intervals of <250 ms during AF and are associated with a higher risk of inducing ventricular fibrillation and sudden death.

 

Pre-excited AF should be treated with electrical cardioversion or IV procainamide or ibutilide, which may terminate the arrhythmia or slow the ventricular rate. AV nodal blockers are absolutely C/I.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia: This is usually a narrow-complex tachycardia, unlike the wide-complex seen in this case.

 

Option C. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: This has a regular rhythm with similar QRS complexes, unlike the irregular pattern seen here.

 

Option D. Torsades de pointes: Difficult to differentiate but the given ECG does not have the twisting morphology to consider it as Torsades de pointes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AF with preexcitation presents with rapid irregular wide-complex tachycardia and it is lethal.

questions.text: Ms. Kavitha, a 22-year-old woman with rheumatic mitral stenosis develops atrial fibrillation. Her CHA₂DS₂-VASc is 1. Which of the following is the correct approach to stroke prevention?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Initiate warfarin

 

Option D:

 

While Ms. Kavitha's CHA₂DS₂-VASc score is 1, her rheumatic mitral stenosis places her at high risk for stroke due to AF. Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant for patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis and AF, as the newer direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) have not been adequately studied in this population.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. No anticoagulation:  Incorrect, since AF increases the risk of stroke by 20-25x in patients with mitral stenosis.

 

Option C. Initiate aspirin 325 mg daily:  Insufficient for stroke prevention in patients with AF and high risk factors like rheumatic mitral stenosis.

 

Option D. Initiate apixaban 5 mg twice daily:  DOACs are not recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis due to limited data.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant for stroke prevention in patients with AF and rheumatic mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. Echo was done and showed severe aortic stenosis, He has hypertension, chronic kidney disease (stage G4), hyperlipidemia, severe COPD, and atrial fibrillation. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI)

 

Option D:

 

TAVI is recommended for symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis who are at high or prohibitive risk for SAVR. TAVI is less invasive than SAVR and has shown similar outcomes in high-risk patients.

 

Option A. Balloon aortic valvuloplasty: Temporary solution, not recommended for definitive treatment of severe AS.

 

Option B. Continued medical therapy: Not appropriate for symptomatic severe AS, as it does not address the underlying valvular issue.

 

Option C. Surgical aortic valve replacement: High risk in this patient due to comorbidities and age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended in preference to surgical aortic valve replacement for symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis who are older than 80 years or younger patients with a life expectancy less than 10 years.

 

Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended for symptomatic patients of any age with severe aortic stenosis and a high or prohibitive surgical risk if predicted post procedure survival is more than 12 months with an acceptable quality of life.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with fatigue and near-syncope with exertion. He has a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bicuspid aortic valve

 

Option A:

 

A systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting is a classic finding of a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV). BAV is a congenital abnormality where the aortic valve has two leaflets instead of three. This can lead to aortic stenosis over time, causing symptoms like fatigue, dyspnea, and syncope with exertion. Squatting increases venous return and left ventricular volume, which accentuates the murmur in aortic stenosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): The murmur of HCM is typically heard best at the left lower sternal border and decreases with squatting.

 

Option C. Restrictive membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSDs typically present with a holosystolic murmur, not a systolic ejection murmur.

 

Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm: This typically presents with a continuous murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting as a classic finding of a bicuspid aortic valve.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents with a 3 hour history of chest pain. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, HR is 120/min and has elevated JVP and clear lungs. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous 0.9% saline

 

Option C:

 

This patient is likely experiencing right ventricular (RV) infarction, a complication of inferior MI. The key features suggestive of RV infarction are hypotension, elevated central venous pressure, clear lungs, and ST-segment elevation in lead V4R. Intravenous fluids are the first-line treatment to increase RV preload and improve cardiac output.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement: Indicated in cardiogenic shock with LV dysfunction, but not the first-line treatment for RV infarction.

 

Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Inotrope may be considered if fluids are ineffective, but not the initial management.

 

Option D. Oral metoprolol: Beta-blockers can worsen hypotension and should be avoided in RV infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patient with an inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement and hypotension should receive intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and severe primary mitral regurgitation (MR) due to mitral valve prolapse has an LVEF of 55% and LV end-systolic dimension of 60 mm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical mitral valve repair

 

Option B:

 

Surgical mitral valve repair is the first-line therapy for patients with primary severe MR who meet the criteria for intervention (symptomatic or asymptomatic with LV enlargement/dysfunction).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): Unnecessary if the mechanism and severity of MR are already established by TTE.

 

Option C. Transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR): Considered in patients with favourable anatomy and high risk for surgical repair.

 

Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): May be helpful if TTE is inconclusive, but not necessary in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery for chronic primary severe mitral regurgitation is indicated in the presence of symptoms, left ventricular dilation, or reduced ejection fraction.

 

Surgical mitral valve repair is first-line therapy for patients with primary severe mitral regurgitation meeting indications for intervention.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin (UFH)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a mechanical mitral valve prosthesis is planning pregnancy. She is currently on warfarin 4mg with a stable INR of 3.0. What is the most appropriate anticoagulation strategy during the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue warfarin

 

Option D:

 

Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant during pregnancy for women with mechanical heart valves if the dose is 5 mg/d or less. It is the most studied anticoagulant in this population and has established safety and efficacy data.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stop warfarin and start Bivalirudin: Not recommended for long-term anticoagulation in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start Dabigatran: Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in pregnancy due to limited safety data.

 

Option C. Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin UFH: Can be considered if warfarin dose is >5 mg/d or if the patient prefers to avoid warfarin during the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves if the dose is ≤5 mg/d.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with exertional dyspnea and elevated BNP. 2D Echo shows EF of 45% and low-flow, low-gradient severe aortic stenosis. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

 

Option B:

 

Dobutamine stress echocardiography is recommended to differentiate between true severe AS and pseudosevere AS (low flow due to reduced LV function).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac catheterization: In this patient who likely has low cardiac output, direct measurement of the aortic valve gradient by cardiac catheterization (Option A) would result in low gradients that underestimate the severity of the AS, similar to gradient and velocity values on resting echocardiography. Dobutamine catheterization may be performed in lieu of dobutamine echocardiography in this case.

 

Option C. & option D. Surgical aortic valve replacement  (SAVR) or Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Proceeding to surgical or transcatheter aortic valve implantation is inappropriate at this time; the resting echo does not adequately differentiate between pseudosevere AS due to insufficient stroke volume and low-flow, low-gradient severe AS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose low-flow, low-gradient severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man had a mechanical mitral valve replacement 1 year ago. He is currently on warfarin and his INR is 3.4. He now presents with easy bruising and scattered ecchymoses. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue current warfarin dosage

 

Option A:

 

This patient has a mechanical heart valve, requiring long-term anticoagulation with warfarin to prevent thromboembolic events. His INR is within the therapeutic range for mechanical mitral valves (2.5-3.5). Easy bruising and ecchymoses are common side effects of warfarin and do not necessarily warrant dose adjustment in the absence of significant bleeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Decreasing warfarin dosage: Would increase the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Option C. Discontinue warfarin and start aspirin: Not sufficient for anticoagulation in patients with mechanical valves.

 

Option D. Discontinue warfarin and start dabigatran: DOACs are not recommended for patients with mechanical valves (based on the data from Re-ALIGN trial).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a prosthetic cardiac valve, the appropriate INR goal varies by type of valve and valve position, with a goal INR of 3.0 (range 2.5-3.5) for a mechanical valve in the mitral position. Dabigatran is associated with excess bleeding and thrombosis, and the safety of other direct oral anticoagulants has not been assessed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of progressive fatigue and dyspnea. Blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg, pulse rate is 76/min, and respiration rate is normal. The apical impulse is slightly sustained but not displaced. Auscultation is performed at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral stenosis

 

Option C:

 

This patient has the typical findings of mitral stenosis, including a diastolic opening snap followed by a long, low-frequency diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. The murmur peaks during mid-diastole and again before a loud S1. The murmur of mitral stenosis is best appreciated by auscultating with the bell of the stethoscope with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation:  Aortic regurgitation produces a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid left sternal border.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation:  Mitral regurgitation produces a high-pitched holosystolic murmur loudest at the cardiac apex.

 

Option D. Pulmonic regurgitation: The murmur of pulmonic regurgitation is early diastolic, best heard over the left second and third interspaces and increases in intensity with inspiration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came for a routine health check-up. She has no symptoms, and on examination, she has a grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex. 2D Echo demonstrates severe Mitral regurgitation with LVEF of 50%. The left ventricle is moderately dilated with an LV end-systolic dimension (LVESD) of 42 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical mitral valve repair

 

Option B:

 

The patient has severe mitral regurgitation (MR) with left ventricular (LV) dilatation. Although she is currently asymptomatic, the presence of severe MR with EF ≤ 60% and LV enlargement (ESD ≥ 40mm) indicates a high risk of future heart failure and adverse outcomes.

 

Repair is preferred over replacement as it preserves the native valve and avoids the need for long-term anticoagulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serial clinical and echocardiographic evaluations: While monitoring is important, it is not the most appropriate next step in this case of severe MR with LV dilatation. Delaying surgery can lead to irreversible LV damage and worsening of symptoms.

 

Option C. Surgical mitral valve replacement: Replacement is considered if repair is not feasible or if the mitral valve is severely damaged. However, repair is the preferred option whenever possible.

 

Option D. Transcatheter mitral valve repair: This is a less invasive option but is currently recommended for patients who are high-risk surgical candidates. This patient is asymptomatic and otherwise healthy, making her a good candidate for surgical repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Indications for surgical mitral valve repair in asymptomatic patients include severe primary MR and LV dilatation (ESD ≥ 40mm and/or EF ≤ 60%).

choices.text: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with acute onset oliguria and elevated creatinine. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and he reports recent episodes of diarrhea and vomiting. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his AKI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prerenal azotemia

 

Option B:

 

The patient's history of hypotension, dehydration (from diarrhea and vomiting), and oliguria strongly suggests prerenal AKI, where decreased renal perfusion is the primary cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): While possible, it's less likely in this scenario without a history of nephrotoxic drug exposure or prolonged hypotension

 

Option C. Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN): This would typically present with fever, rash, or other signs of allergic reaction.

 

Option D. Postrenal obstruction: Less likely given the absence of urinary symptoms suggestive of obstruction

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the different causes of acute kidney injury (AKI) and to be able to identify prerenal azotemia as the most likely cause in a patient with hypotension, dehydration, and oliguria. Prerenal azotemia is a functional AKI caused by decreased blood flow to the kidneys, often due to volume depletion or low blood pressure.

choices.text: A 40-year-old with baseline creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL, current creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL, and urine output of 0.4 mL/kg/hour for 18 hours.
A 25-year-old with a baseline creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, current creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL, and anuria for 14 hours.
A 50-year-old with a baseline creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, current creatinine of 1.5 mg/dL, and anuria for 10 hours.
A 15-year-old with a decrease in eGFR to 30 mL/min/1.73 m².

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would classify a patient as having Stage 3 AKI?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A 15-year-old with a decrease in eGFR to 30 mL/min/1.73 m².

 

Explanation:

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with recurrent chest pain and dyspnea. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical exam reveals elevated JVP, crackles, and a soft early systolic murmur with an S3 gallop. ECG is shown. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary congestion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral regurgitation

 

Option C:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with acute mitral regurgitation (MR) secondary to an inferolateral myocardial infarction (MI). The ECG findings is suggestive of inferior MI with possible posterior MI (see lead V2) and its likely that posteromedial papillary muscle is ruptured in this case (which is supplied by the RCA), leading to Acute MR. The clinical findings of elevated JVP, pulmonary congestion, and an S3 gallop support the diagnosis of acute heart failure, which is a consequence of the severe MR. The soft early systolic murmur and diastolic rumble are also characteristic of MR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: While this can cause heart failure, it would present with a harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids, not a soft early systolic murmur.

 

Option B. Cardiac tamponade: This can cause elevated JVP and distant heart sounds, but it would not typically present with a new murmur or ECG changes of MI.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration, not the early systolic murmur described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute MR usually occurs in association with inferior MI and it is due to rupture of posteromedial papillary muscle.

choices.text: Esmolol continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of connective tissue disease presents with acute shortness of breath and pulmonary edema. Examination reveals severe aortic regurgitation due to a right coronary cusp avulsion. She is in cardiogenic shock. What intervention is most likely to maintain end-organ perfusion until surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV nitroprusside

 

Option C:

 

The patient is experiencing acute, severe aortic regurgitation leading to cardiogenic shock. The goal is to reduce regurgitant blood volume and improve forward flow. Nitroprusside, a vasodilator, decreases systemic vascular resistance (afterload), reducing the pressure gradient driving the regurgitant flow back into the left ventricle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esmolol (beta-blocker) continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min: Slowing the heart rate increases diastolic time, worsening regurgitation.

 

Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump: Contraindicated in severe aortic regurgitation, as it inflates during diastole, further increasing regurgitation.

 

Option D. IV norepinephrine: IV norepinephrine and E. Vasopressin: These are vasopressors that increase afterload, which would worsen aortic regurgitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute severe aortic regurgitation with cardiogenic shock, IV nitroprusside can be used as a bridge to surgery by reducing afterload and improving forward flow.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presented with fatigue. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mitral stenosis

 

Option A:

 

The image shows a characteristic pressure tracing of mitral stenosis. The key features that point towards this diagnosis are:

 

Elevated left atrial pressure (LA): The red line (LA pressure) is significantly higher than the left ventricular pressure (LV pressure) during diastole. This indicates a pressure gradient across the mitral valve, suggesting stenosis (narrowing).

 

Diastolic pressure gradient: The shaded area between the LA and LV pressure curves during diastole represents the pressure gradient across the mitral valve. In mitral stenosis, this gradient is elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis: This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.

 

Option D. Aortic regurgitation: This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LA-LV gradient during diastole is characteristic of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chest pain. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aortic stenosis

 

Option B:

 

The key finding in the image is a significant pressure gradient between the left ventricle (LV) and the aorta during systole. This pressure gradient indicates that the blood flow from the LV to the aorta is obstructed, which is a hallmark of LVOT obstruction like aortic stenosis. Common symptoms of aortic stenosis include chest pain, syncope and dyspnea (especially during exertion).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mitral stenosis: This would show a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.

 

Option D. Aortic regurgitation: This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pressure gradient between the LV and the aorta during systole is hallmark of LVOT obstruction (like aortic stenosis).

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with transient right-sided weakness. Evaluation reveals a small ischemic stroke and a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with right-to-left shunt. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PFO device closure

 

Option B:

 

In patients younger than 60 years with a PFO and an embolic stroke of undetermined source, PFO closure is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Antiplatelet therapy alone is less effective than PFO closure in preventing recurrent stroke.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Anticoagulation may be considered in older patients or those with contraindications to PFO closure.

 

Option D. Observation: Not appropriate due to the high risk of recurrent stroke in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PFO closure is recommended for younger patients (< 60y) with cryptogenic stroke and PFO to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

choices.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea, a systolic murmur at the left second intercostal space, a diastolic flow rumble over the tricuspid valve, and fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2). ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial septal defect (ASD)

 

Option A:

 

The combination of the murmur, fixed splitting of S2, ECG findings (right axis deviation, incomplete RBBB), and right heart enlargement on chest x-ray are characteristic of an ASD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR: Would have a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border.

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis: Would have a diastolic murmur at the apex.

 

Option D. VSD: Typically presents with a holosystolic murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical and ECG findings suggestive of an ASD.

 

as amyloidosis, should be considered. Serum protein electrophoresis/urine protein electrophoresis and free light-chain analysis may help identify immunoglobulin light-chain amyloidosis.

choices.text: Ostium secundum atrial septal defect

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. On physical examination, a parasternal impulse is noted at the left sternal border. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard at the second left intercostal space with fixed splitting of the S2.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ostium secundum atrial septal defect

 

Option B:

 

The most likely diagnosis is ostium secundum atrial septal defect (ASD). This ECG demonstrates the typical findings associated with an ostium secundum ASD, including right axis deviation (negative QRS in lead I with positive QRS in leads II, III, and aVF) and incomplete right bundle branch block (QRS duration <120 ms, prominent S wave in lateral leads, and prominent qR in V1). ASDs are generally classified by their location. Ostium secundum ASDs, the most common type of ASD (75% of cases), are located in the mid portion of the atrial septum and are usually isolated anomalies. Symptoms may include fatigue, exertional dyspnea, arrhythmias, and paradoxical embolism. Clinical findings in patients with an ASD include a parasternal impulse, fixed splitting of the S2, and a pulmonary outflow murmur. A diastolic flow rumble across the tricuspid valve can occur with a large left-to-right shunt.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with palpitations and syncope. On examination, he has a systolic click with a pansystolic murmur in the left lower sternal border and an elevated JVP. He also complains of intermittent bluish discoloration of face during exercise since childhood. ECG is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ebstein's Anomaly

 

Option C:

 

The patient's clinical presentation aligns with the characteristic features of Ebstein's anomaly: Systolic click and pansystolic murmur (suggestive of TR), Elevated JVP (due to TR), intermittent cyanosis with exertion (due to right-to-left shunting through an ASD) and tall P waves and right axis deviation on ECG (indicate right atrial enlargement).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ASD: While ASD can be present in Ebstein's anomaly, it alone does not explain all the clinical features in this case.

 

Option B. VSD: VSD presents with a harsh holosystolic murmur but not the other findings in this case.

 

Option D. TOF: TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart defect with a different murmur pattern (harsh systolic ejection murmur) and ECG findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Very tall (Himalayan) P waves are a hallmark of Ebstein’s anomaly.

choices.text: Atrial septal defect with shunt reversal
D-transposition of the great arteries
Patent ductus arteriosus with shunt reversal
Ventricular septal defect with shunt reversal

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy from a rural area in tamilnadu presents with fatigue during physical activity, clubbing, and cyanosis in his feet. His hands appear normal. What is the most likely congenital abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patent ductus arteriosus with shunt reversal

 

Option C:

 

The patient's differential cyanosis (cyanosis in the lower extremities but not the upper) strongly suggests a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with Eisenmenger syndrome. In this condition, pulmonary hypertension develops, reversing the shunt through the PDA and causing deoxygenated blood to flow into the descending aorta.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrial septal defect with shunt reversal: While ASDs can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, the cyanosis would be central, affecting both upper and lower extremities.

 

Option B. D-transposition of the great arteries: This typically presents with severe central cyanosis (nit differential) shortly after birth, not later in childhood.

 

Option D. Ventricular septal defect with shunt reversal: Similar to ASD, VSDs can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, but cyanosis would be central, not differential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential cyanosis (lower extremity cyanosis with sparing of the upper extremities) is a hallmark of a PDA with Eisenmenger syndrome.

choices.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic diameter <45 mm
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return without pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following congenital cardiovascular abnormalities would provide the highest maternal risk in the setting of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe native aortic coarctation

 

Option C:

 

Severe native aortic coarctation poses the highest maternal risk during pregnancy due to the increased risk of aortic dissection or rupture. The elevated blood pressure and increased cardiac output during pregnancy can put significant stress on the narrowed aorta.

 

Risk of cardiac disease and pregnancy is summarised below -

 

WHO Class I: MVP, PDA, PS, repaired ASD/VSD, isolated APC/VPC.

 

WHO Class II: Unrepaired ASD/VSD, repaired TOF, most arrhythmias.

 

WHO Class II-III: Repaired CoA, HCM, Mild LV dysfunction, Marfan without AoD, BAV + Ao < 4.5cm

 

WHO Class III: CyCHD, Fontan, systemic RV, Marfan + Ao ≥ 4cm, BAV + Ao ≥ 4.5cm, Mechanical valve

 

WHO Class IV (pregnancy C/I): PAH, LVEF < 30%, severe CoA, Marfan + Ao ≥ 4.5cm, BAV + Ao ≥ 5cm, severe MS/AS, PPCM with residual LV dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic diameter <45 mm: While a bicuspid aortic valve can be associated with aortic dilation, the risk is lower if the aortic diameter is less than 45 mm.

 

Option B. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return without pulmonary hypertension: This condition is generally well-tolerated and poses a lower risk in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Systemic right ventricle: While this can be associated with complex congenital heart disease, it does not carry the same immediate risk of aortic complications as severe coarctation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe aortic coarctation is a high-risk condition in pregnancy due to the increased risk of aortic dissection or rupture.

choices.text: Colchicine and intravenous immune globulin (IVIG)

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent pericarditis. He has had two prior episodes, both successfully treated with ibuprofen and colchicine. His current symptoms include fever, pulsus paradoxus, a pericardial friction rub, and widespread ST-segment elevation on ECG. Echocardiogram shows a small pericardial effusion without tamponade. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ibuprofen, colchicine, and prednisone

 

Option D:

 

This patient has recurrent pericarditis, defined as a recurrence after a symptom-free interval of 4-6 weeks following the initial episode. Since he has already been treated with ibuprofen and colchicine, the most appropriate treatment for this recurrence is triple therapy with ibuprofen, colchicine, and a glucocorticoid like prednisone. This combination has been shown to be more effective in reducing recurrence rates compared to colchicine and NSAIDs alone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anakinra: This is an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist used for refractory cases of recurrent pericarditis that have not responded to other treatments.

 

Option B. Colchicine and IVIG: This combination is also used for refractory cases, but glucocorticoids should be added first.

 

Option C. Ibuprofen alone: Unlikely to be effective for recurrent pericarditis, especially since it has been used previously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with recurrent pericarditis initially treated with both colchicine and an NSAID, the addition of a glucocorticoid should be considered.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man had an atrial septal defect (ASD) closure one year ago. He is now scheduled for tooth extraction and periodontal cleaning. The dentist recommended a nil per oral (NPO) 8 hours prior to the procedure. What is the choice for IE prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No endocarditis prophylaxis

 

Option D:

 

IE prophylaxis is not recommended for patients with repaired ASDs who do not have residual shunts or other high-risk features.

 

IE prophylaxis is indicated only for patients at high risk for infective endocarditis who are about to undergo gingival manipulation or other procedures that break the oral mucosa.

 

The highest risk for IE is in patients with a prosthetic valve, previous IE, or cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease with residual flow disturbances. Other indications include cardiac transplantation valvulopathy, prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, and a cardiac defect that has been repaired with prosthetic material within the previous 6 months.

 

Explanation:

 

A), B), C): These are antibiotics used for endocarditis prophylaxis but are not indicated in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endocarditis prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for dental procedures in patients with repaired ASDs unless there are specific high-risk features.

questions.text: A patient evaluated for cough is found to have an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiography. He is suspected of having pericardial effusion. Ultrasonography is performed with the probe placed in the subxiphoid area. The results are shown. Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of this study?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Large pericardial effusion

 

Option A:

 

This patient's ultrasound shows a large, circumferential pericardial effusion (arrows) with evidence of cardiac tamponade. An anechoic space is seen between the liver in the near field and the myocardium of the heart and also surrounds the entire heart, indicating a large effusion. Cardiac tamponade is typically seen as collapse of the right atrium or the right ventricle during the diastolic phase of the cardiac cycle. In this study, although the right ventricular free wall appears to “wiggle,” this is caused by inward diastolic movement typical in tamponade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. No pericardial effusion: This option is incorrect because the ultrasound clearly demonstrates the presence of a significant anechoic space around the heart, indicating a pericardial effusion.

 

Option C. LV dilatation: Left ventricular (LV) dilatation is not indicated by the findings described in this scenario. The primary abnormality is the pericardial effusion, not an intrinsic abnormality of the left ventricle.

 

Option D. Indeterminate study: This option is incorrect because the ultrasound findings are definitive for a large pericardial effusion. There is no indication that the study is inconclusive or indeterminate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A large pericardial effusion is characterized by the accumulation of fluid around the heart, visible as an anechoic space on ultrasound. It can lead to cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with SLE presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, chest fullness, and bilateral peripheral edema. She is febrile and her JVP is elevated. ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

 

The patient's clinical presentation, including fever, jugular venous distention and electrical alternans on ECG are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition where fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac compresses the heart, impairing its ability to pump blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Constrictive pericarditis: Although it can present with similar symptoms, it usually has a more insidious onset and does not typically cause electrical alternans on ECG.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism: Can cause dyspnea and elevated JVP, but it would not typically present with electrical alternans.

 

Option D. Pulmonary hypertension: Less likely in the absence of lung disease or right heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical alternans is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of fever, malaise, and heart murmur. Today, crops of nonpainful cutaneous lesions have appeared on his feet as shown. Given the diagnosis, the patient is at risk of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aortic dissection

 

Option D:

 

The image demonstrates Janeway lesions. These are nonpainful, macular (occasionally nodular), blanching lesions located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; they  are associated with infective endocarditis and considered to be a part of vascular phenomenon.

 

Coming back to the case - fever, malaise and a new heart murmur also strongly suggests infective endocarditis. While IE can rarely cause mycotic aneurysms (common the brain), aortic dissection is not a direct complication of infective endocarditis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intracranial hemorrhage: Septic emboli from IE can lodge in the brain, causing intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Stroke: Septic emboli can also cause ischemic stroke.

 

Option C. Heart failure: Valve damage from IE can lead to heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic complications are uncommon in endocarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for chronic right-sided heart failure. Chest radiographs are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constrictive pericarditis

 

Option B:

 

The most likely diagnosis is constrictive pericarditis. This chest radiograph shows pericardial calcification on both the posterior-anterior (black arrow) and lateral views (white arrows). Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by pericardial thickening, fibrosis, and sometimes calcification that impair diastolic filling and limit total cardiac volume. Chest radiography or CT may demonstrate partial or circumferential pericardial calcification, and CT or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging may demonstrate pericardial thickening (>3 mm). Importantly, constriction may exist in the absence of these findings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension: This condition involves pulmonary artery obstruction due to organized clots, leading to increased pulmonary artery pressure and right-sided heart failure. However, it would not typically present with pericardial calcification on chest radiographs.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism: While primary hyperparathyroidism can cause hypercalcemia and possibly lead to calcifications in various tissues, it is not typically associated with pericardial calcification or the symptoms of chronic right-sided heart failure.

 

Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction due to myocardial stiffness but does not involve pericardial calcification. The imaging findings and clinical presentation are more consistent with constrictive pericarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by pericardial thickening and calcification that leads to impaired cardiac filling and chronic right-sided heart failure. Radiographic evidence of pericardial calcification is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presents with edema and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP). The JVP pressure tracing is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constrictive pericarditis

 

Option B:

 

The combination of edema, elevated JVP, and prominent x and y descents on the JVP tracing is highly suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

 

  • Prominent x descent: This reflects the rapid atrial emptying during early ventricular systole due to the rigid pericardium limiting ventricular filling.
  • Prominent y descent: This represents the rapid ventricular filling during early diastole as the tricuspid valve opens, also due to the constraint imposed by the pericardium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: In cardiac tamponade, the x descent is typically absent or minimal, and the y descent is blunted or slow.

 

Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a prominent v wave in the JVP tracing, not a prominent x descent.

 

Option D. Tricuspid stenosis: Tricuspid stenosis would cause a slow y descent, but the x descent would be normal or blunted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prominent x and y descent is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis. The prominent ‘y’ descent of constrictive pericarditis is also called as ‘friedrich sign’.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with pleuritic chest pain, fever, and malaise two weeks after a myocardial infarction (MI). On auscultation, you hear a multiphasic rub. His CRP levels are elevated, and troponin levels are slightly elevated but unchanged compared to previous values. ECG shows new ST elevations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dressler's syndrome

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is classic for Dressler's syndrome:

 

  • Timing: Occurs 1-8 weeks after MI.
  • Symptoms: Pleuritic chest pain, fever, malaise.
  • Exam: Pericardial friction rub.
  • Labs: Elevated CRP, slightly elevated but unchanged troponin.
  • ECG: New ST elevations (due to pericardial inflammation).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute pericarditis: Less likely given the recent MI.

 

Option C. Pulmonary embolism: Unlikely with unchanged troponin and ECG findings.

 

Option D. Recurrent MI: Unlikely with unchanged troponin and ECG findings suggestive of pericarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dressler's syndrome is a post-MI pericarditis that occurs after 1-2 weeks.

questions.text: A 38-year-old homeless man presents with TIA, fever, chills, tender splenomegaly, new painful nodules on fingers, and nits on clothes. Blood cultures are negative, but echo reveals aortic valve vegetation. What test should be sent to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bartonella serology

 

Option A:

 

This patient has culture-negative endocarditis. Culture-negative endocarditis accounts for <10% of cases in all populations.

 

A common reason for negative blood cultures is prior antibiotics. In the absence of this, the two most common pathogens are Q fever, or Coxiella burnetii (typically associated with close contact with livestock), and Bartonella. In this case, the patient’s homelessness and body louse infestation are clues for B. quintana infection.

 

Diagnosis is made by blood culture about 25% of the time. Otherwise, direct PCR of valvular tissue, if available, or acute and convalescent serologies are diagnostic options. Empirical therapy for culture-negative endocarditis usually includes ceftriaxone + gentamicin, with or without doxycycline.

 

For confirmed Bartonella endocarditis, optimal therapy is gentamicin + doxycycline

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus heterophile antibody: EBV does not typically cause endocarditis.

 

Option C. HIV polymerase chain reaction: HIV does not cause endocarditis.

 

Option D. Q fever serology: While Q fever can cause culture-negative endocarditis, the patient's history and presentation are more consistent with Bartonella infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Two most common pathogens responsible for culture negative endocarditis re

choices.text: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
Minimal change disease

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese woman with controlled hypertension has nephrotic-range proteinuria and mild edema. Renal biopsy reveals segmental scarring in 60% of glomeruli, mainly at the corticomedullary junction. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

 

Option A:

 

FSGS: The biopsy finding of segmental scarring in a subset of glomeruli, especially in the corticomedullary junction, is characteristic of FSGS. Additionally, the patient's obesity is a known risk factor for FSGS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis: While the patient has hypertension, the biopsy findings do not fit the typical pattern of nephrosclerosis (arteriolosclerosis and global glomerulosclerosis).

 

Option C. Minimal change disease: This would usually present with less severe proteinuria and no glomerular scarring on biopsy.

 

Option D. Crescentic glomerulonephritis: This is a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis with crescents (proliferations of cells) on biopsy, not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by segmental scarring in a subset of glomeruli, often associated with obesity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with multiple violet-colored skin lesions and lymphadenopathy. The lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent for his skin condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Option A.

 

The presentation is consistent with Kaposi sarcoma (KS), a malignancy strongly associated with HHV-8 infection, particularly in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV. While EBV can cause lymphoma, it doesn't typically present with skin lesions. HPV is linked to various cancers but not KS. HTLV-1 causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, which has a different presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): While EBV is associated with several malignancies (lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma), it doesn't typically cause the characteristic skin lesions seen in Kaposi sarcoma.

 

Option C. Human papillomavirus (HPV): HPV is primarily associated with cervical cancer and other anogenital cancers. It doesn't cause the type of lesions seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1): HTLV-1 is associated with adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, a type of blood cancer. It doesn't usually cause the distinctive skin lesions of Kaposi sarcoma.

 

Educational objective:

HHV-8 is the causative agent of Kaposi sarcoma, a malignancy often seen in HIV-infected individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following types of UV radiation is MOST strongly linked to the development of skin cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) UVB

 

Option B.

 

UVB radiation is a type of ultraviolet radiation that has a shorter wavelength than UVA but a longer wavelength than UVC. It is the most damaging type of UV radiation that reaches the Earth's surface. UVB radiation is absorbed by the DNA in skin cells, causing damage that can lead to mutations and the development of skin cancer.  

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. gamma rays: Gamma rays are a type of ionizing radiation with very short wavelengths and high energy. While they are carcinogenic, they are not the primary type of radiation associated with skin cancer.  

 

Option C. x-rays: X-rays are also a type of ionizing radiation with shorter wavelengths than UV radiation. They are used in medical imaging and can also be carcinogenic, but their primary association is not with skin cancer.  

 

Option D. alpha-rays: Alpha rays are a type of particle radiation consisting of two protons and two neutrons. They have low penetrating power and are not associated with skin cancer.

 

Educational objective:

UVB radiation is the most significant contributor to skin cancer development.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with hematuria and edema, three weeks after a confirmed case of impetigo. Which of the following is the most appropriate time frame for the development of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) following impetigo?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2-6 weeks

 

Option B:

 

The typical time frame for the development of PSGN after impetigo is 2-6 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1-3 weeks: This time frame is too short for PSGN to develop after a streptococcal infection like impetigo.

 

Option C. 3-8 weeks: While PSGN can occasionally present slightly later, the most typical window is within the first 2-6 weeks.

 

Option D. 2-6 days: This time frame is far too short. PSGN takes weeks, not days, to manifest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-mediated complication that can occur after a streptococcal infection. The classic presentation includes hematuria (blood in the urine), edema (swelling) and hypertension. The most common time frame for the development of PSGN following a streptococcal infection is 2-6 weeks. Recognizing this typical time frame is crucial for timely diagnosis and management of PSGN.

choices.text: Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane
Subepithelial immune complex deposits

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with hemoptysis (coughing up blood), shortness of breath and hematuria. His serum creatinine is elevated. A renal biopsy is taken and immunofluorescence is shown below. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be the immunofluorescence findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane

 

Option B:

 

Linear IgG deposits on immunofluorescence are a hallmark of anti-GBM disease, the underlying cause of Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mesangial cell proliferation: Is seen in IgA nephropathy and other conditions.

 

Option C. Subepithelial immune complex deposits: Are characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Mesangial IgA deposits: Are seen in IgA nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome (anti-GBM disease).

choices.text: Thin basement membrane nephropathy (TBMN)
Minimal change disease (MCD)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease, on further questioning he has difficulty in hearing since childhood. A renal biopsy reveals thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alport syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Thin GBM is an early and characteristic finding in young Alport syndrome patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IgA nephropathy: Presents with mesangial IgA deposits.

 

Option B. Thin basement membrane nephropathy (TBMN): This is a benign condition with persistent thin GBM, but no progression to multilamellation or other Alport features.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease (MCD): Does not cause thinning of the GBM.

 

Educational objective:

 

  •  Alport syndrome is primarily inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern (approximately 85%), but 15% of cases follow an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy, combined with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease and hearing loss, are suggestive of Alport syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperkalemia

 

Option D:

 

Hyperkalemia is not a characteristic finding in nephrotic syndrome. In fact, hypokalemia can occur due to diuretic use or other factors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proteinuria > 3.5 g/day: This is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome. The excessive loss of protein in the urine is a defining characteristic.

 

Option B. Hypoalbuminemia: This occurs due to the significant loss of albumin (a protein) in the urine, leading to low albumin levels in the blood.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: The liver tries to compensate for the protein loss by increasing the production of lipids (fats), leading to high levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by a constellation of findings, including heavy proteinuria, low albumin levels, and elevated lipids. Hyperkalemia (high potassium) is not typically associated with nephrotic syndrome; in fact, hypokalemia (low potassium) is more common due to urinary losses.

choices.text: Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits
Mesangial electron-dense deposits
Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane
Effacement of podocyte foot processes

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be electron microscopic findings would be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Effacement of podocyte foot processes

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation of generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia is consistent with nephrotic syndrome. In children, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome is minimal change disease. The hallmark of MCD on electron microscopy is the effacement of podocyte foot processes, which are essential for the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits: This is typically seen in lupus nephritis and other immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis.

 

Option B. Mesangial electron-dense deposits: This is characteristic of IgA nephropathy.

 

Option C. Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane: This is seen in thin basement membrane nephropathy, a benign condition with minimal proteinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests minimal change disease (MCD), which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The hallmark electron microscopic finding in MCD is the effacement (flattening or fusion) of podocyte foot processes. These foot processes are crucial for the filtration barrier in the glomerulus and their damage leads to the massive proteinuria seen in nephrotic syndrome.

choices.text: MPGN type I
MPGN type II
MPGN type III

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with “tram-track” appearance of renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) MPGN type I

 

Option A:

 

The "tram-track" appearance is due to mesangial interposition between the GBM and endothelial cells, a characteristic finding in MPGN type I.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. MPGN type II:  Shows dense deposits within the GBM, not the tram-track appearance.

 

Option C. MPGN type III:  Is similar to type I but with less prominent mesangial interposition.

 

Option D. Alport syndrome: Shows splitting and lamellation of the GBM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "tram-track" appearance on renal biopsy is a hallmark of MPGN type I due to the characteristic mesangial interposition. This distinctive finding helps differentiate MPGN type I from other glomerular diseases.

choices.text: The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years.
Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis.
Approximately 50% of patients will develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.
Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is newly diagnosed with idiopathic membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I. Which of the following statements regarding their prognosis is MOST accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Approximately 50% of patients will develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.

 

Option C:

 

MPGN type I is a progressive disease, and studies have shown that about 50% of patients will develop ESRD within 10 years of diagnosis. This underscores the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management to slow disease progression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years:  Spontaneous remission is rare in MPGN type I.

 

Option B. Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis:  Renal function typically declines over time, with 90% of patients developing renal insufficiency within 20 years.

 

Option D. Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases:  While corticosteroids may be beneficial in some cases, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPGN type I is a progressive disease with a poor prognosis. Approximately half of the patients progress to ESRD within 10 years, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and management to potentially slow disease progression. While treatments like corticosteroids may be used, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.
